question: Well, you know how it is, I, I've just got to keep working. See?
answer: Sorry, sister. I was sent down here to clean house. I told yuh I can't use your column any more. It's lavender and old lace! Send those other people in.

question: I'll tell you what I'll do. I get thirty dollars a week. I'll take twenty-five, twenty if necessary. I'll do anything you say.
answer: It isn't the money. We're after circulation. What we need is fireworks. People who can hit with sledge hammersstart arguments.

question: Oh, I can do that. I know this town inside out. Oh, give me a chance, please.
answer: All right, come in, come in! Come in! Don't forget to get out your last column before you pick up your check!

question: You're a couple o' sticks shy in your column, Ann. Did you get it, too?
answer: Yeah. You, too? Oh, Joe . . . oh, I'm sorry darling . . . why don't we tear the building down!

question: Before you do, Ann, perhaps you'd better finish this column.
answer: Yeah. Lavender and old lace! Wait, Joewait! Here.

question: Hey, Ann, this is the old fakeroo, isn't it?
answer: Never mind that, Joe. Go ahead.

question: Spencer of the Chronicle .
answer: Hold him. Yes, Spencer. Who? The Governor? Well, what about me? it's my building he's jumping off of! And I'm up for re-election, too!

question: Shh! What?
answer: Out the window! Something just flew by!

question: I didn't see anything.
answer: Is there a crowd in the street?

question: No, sir.
answer: Then he may be caught on a ledge! Look again!

question: I think it must have been a sea-gull.
answer: A sea-gull? What's a sea-gull doing around the city hall? That's a bad omen, isn't it?

question: Oh, n-no, sir. The sea-gull is a lovely bird.
answer: Hello! Connell! This is

question: Yes, Mayor Lovett! How many times are you gonna call me? I've got everybody and his brother and sister out looking for him. Did you see the box I'm running?
answer: I went up to Miss Mitchell's house, boss. Boy, she's in a bad way.

question: Where is she?
answer: Hey, do you know something? She supports a mother and two kids. What do you know about that? No. Her mother's awful worried about her. When she left the house she said she was going on a roaring drunk. Er, the girl, I mean! Sure. Hey, but the biggest thing I didn't tell you . . .

question: Hello! . . . Yeh?
answer: Her old man was Doc Mitchell. You know, the doc that saved my mother's life and wouldn't take any money for it? You remember that? Okay, boss, I'll go and look for her.

question: I remember, distinctly, being fired.
answer: That's right. But you have a piece of property that still belongs to this newspaper. And I'd like to have it!

question: What's that?
answer: The letter.

question: What letter?
answer: The letter from John Doe.

question: Oh!
answer: The whole town's in an uproar. We've got to find him. The letter's our only clue. We'll get a handwriting expert to

question: There is no letter.
answer: Say that again.

question: There is no letter. I made it up. Uh-huh. You said you wanted fireworks.
answer: Don't you know there are nine jobs waiting for this guy? Twenty-two families want to board him free? Five women want to marry him, and the Mayor's practically ready to adopt him? And you . . .

question: Don't you know there are nine jobs waiting for this guy? Twenty-two families want to board him free? Five women want to marry him, and the Mayor's practically ready to adopt him? And you . . .
answer: I just called the morgue, boss. They say there's a girl there

question: Shut up!
answer: Ann! Say, why didn't yuh

question: Beany!
answer: Only one thing to do, Hank. Drop the whole business quickly.

question: How?
answer: Run a story. Say John Doe was in here, and is sorry he wrote the letter and

question: I got a story I want yuh to
answer: Wait a minute! Listen, you great big wonderful genius of a newspaperman! You came down here to shoot some life into this dying paper, didn't you? Well, the whole town's curious about John Doe and, boom, just like that you're going to bury him. There's enough circulation in that man to start a shortage in the ink market! John Doe.

question: What John Doe?
answer: Our John Doe! The one I made up! Look, genius Now, look. Suppose there was a John Doeand he walked into this office. What would you do? Find him a job and forget about the whole business, I suppose! Not me! I'd have made a deal with him!

question: A deal?
answer: Sure! When you get hold of a stunt that sells papers you don't drop it like a hot potato. Why, this is good for at least a couple of months. You know what I'd do? Between now and let's say, Christmas, when he's gonna jump, I'd run a daily yarn starting with his boyhood, his schooling, his first job! A wide-eyed youngster facing a chaotic world. The problem of the average man, of all the John Does in the world. Now, then comes the drama. He meets discouragement. He finds the world has feet of clay. His ideals crumble. So what does he do? He decides to commit suicide in protest against the state of civilization. He thinks of the river! But no, no, he has a better idea. The City Hall. Why? Because he wants to attract attention. He wants to get a few things off his chest, and that's the only way he can get himself heard.

question: So?
answer: So! So he writes me a letter and I dig him up. He pours out his soul to me, and from now on we quote John Doe.

question: Who, for instance?
answer: Anybody! Er, erBeany'll do!

question: No, no, no, the gal's right. We can't let the Chronicle get the laugh on us! We've got to produce a John Doe now.
answer: Sureand there's no reason for them to find out the truth, either. Plus a bonus.

question: What bonus? I can read. I can read!
answer: Sorry.

question: Well, the paper said there were some jobs around loose. Thought there might be one left over.
answer: Had any schooling?

question: Yeah, a little.
answer: What do you do when you work? Baseball?

question: Uh-huh. Till my wing went bad.
answer: Where'd you play?

question: Er, would you, er, would you like to make some money?
answer: Yeah, maybe.

question: Would you be willing to say you wrote that letterand stick by it?
answer: Oh, I get the idea. Yeah, maybe.

question: That's our man. He's made to order.
answer: I don't know. He don't seem like a guy that'd fall into line.

question: He's fainted! Get some water quickly!
answer: Hurry up, Pop.

question: Oh.
answer: Huh?

question: Are you all right?
answer: Yeah, I'm all right.

question: How many is that, six? Pretty hungry, weren't you?
answer: Say, all this John Doe business is batty, if yuh ask me.

question: Well, nobody asked yuh.
answer: Trying to improve the world by jumping off buildings. You couldn't improve the world if the building jumped on you!

question: All right, boys, here he is. But, he's gonna jump off a building!
answer: Yes, but not because he's out of a job. That's not news! This man's going to jump as a matter of principle.

question: Well, maybe you're right.
answer: We'll clean him up and put him in a hotel roomunder bodyguards. We'll make a mystery out of him. Oh, swell! Is that the contract?

question: Yes.
answer: Friend of his. They play duets together.

question: Duets? But can we trust him?
answer: Oh!

question: Oh, you trust him, eh? Well, that's fine. I suppose he trusts you, too?
answer: Oh, stop worrying. He's all right.

question: Well, okay. But we don't want more than a couple o' hundred people in on this thing. Now the first thing I want is an exact copy of the John Doe letter in your own handwriting.
answer: I got it all ready. Here.

question: The next thing the dope wants is a room. Yessir, a room with steam heat! And curtains and rugs I seen plenty of fellers start out with fifty bucks and wind up with a bank account!
answer: Who's got him?

question: The heelots!
answer: Who? Who's got him?

question: Hey, Doc, look. Look, Doc. Gimme that again, will yuh? Who's gonna get him?
answer: The heelots!

question: Who are they?
answer: Listen, sucker, yuh ever been broke?

question: Sure. Mostly often.
answer: All right. You're walking alongnot a nickel in your jeansfree as the windnobody bothers youhundreds of people pass yuh by in every line of businessshoes, hats, automobiles, radio, furniture, everything. They're all nice, lovable people, and they let you alone. Is that right? All those nice, sweet, lovable people become heelots. A lotta heels. Now your whole life is messed up with more stufflicense feesand number platesand gas and oiland taxes and insurance And a million and one other things. And what happens? You're not the free and happy guy you used to be. You gotta have money to pay for all those thingsso you go after what the other feller's got

question: Here. Sit down! Oh, come on, now. This is serious. You're a man disgusted with all of civilization.
answer: With all of it?

question: Yes, you're sore at the world. Come on, now.
answer: Oh, crabby guy, huh?

question: Yeah. No, no!
answer: Well, all those guys in the bleachers think

question: Never mind those guys. All right, stand up. Now let's see what you look like when you protest.
answer: Against what?

question: Against anything. Just protest. Oh, look. I'm the umpire, and you just cut the heart of the plate with your fast one and I call it a ball. What would you do? Yes!
answer: Why can't you call right, you bone-headed, pig-eared, lop-eared, pot-bellied

question: You should see his fan mail! Thousands! Why, it's going over like a house afire!
answer: Yeah, but it's got everybody sore. Ads are being pulledthe Governor's starting a libel suitwhat's more, they all know John Doe's a phoneyand they insist on seeing him.

question: Well, what about it? Let them see him! We'll go them one better. They can also hear him. Ohh!
answer: Look. We can't let 'em get to this bush-league pitcher and start pumping him. Good night! No telling what that screwball might do. I walked in yesterdayhere he is, standing on a table with a fishing pole flycasting. Take my advice and get him out of town before this thing explodes in our faces!

question: Yes, sir. Oh! Hey! Oh, hey! I thought you were asleep! Oh, oh! Oh, you little brats! You're just stalling. I said good night!
answer: Go on! Now, keep Pooch off the bed.

question: Stick a fork through me! I'm done. I'll never get this speech right.
answer: Oh, yes you will, Ann dear . . . you're very clever.

question: Yeah, I know. What are you looking for?
answer: Your purse. I need ten dollars.

question: What for? I gave you fifty just the other day.
answer: Yes, I know, dear, but Mrs. Burke had her baby yesterday. Nine pounds! And there wasn't a thing in the houseand then this morning the Community Chest lady came around and

question: And the fifty's all gone, huh? Who's the ten for?
answer: The Websters.

question: The Websters!
answer: You remember those lovely people your father used to take care of? I thought I'd buy them some groceries. Oh, Ann, dear, it's a shame, those poor

question: You're marvelous, Ma. You're just like Father used to be. Do you realize a couple of weeks ago we didn't have enough to eat ourselves?
answer: Well, yes, I know, dear, but these people are in such need and we have plenty now.

question: Oh, I'm sorry, Ma. Oh, don't pay any attention to me. I guess I'm just upset about all this. Gee whiz, here I am with a great opportunity to get somewhere, to give us security for once in our lives, and I'm stuck. If I could put this over, your Mrs. Burke can have six babies!
answer: Do you mean the speech you're writing?

question: Yeah, I don't know. I simply can't get it to jell! I created somebody who's gonna give up his life for a principle, hundreds of thousands of people are gonna listen to him over the radio and, unless he says something that's, well, that's sensational, it's just no good!
answer: Well, honey, of course I don't know what kind of a speech you're trying to write, but judging from the samples I've read, I don't think anybody'll listen.

question: What?
answer: Darling, there are so many complaining political speeches. People are tired of hearing nothing but doom and despair on the radio. If you're going to have him say anything, why don't you let him say something simple and real, something with hope in it? If your father were alive, he'd know what to say.

question: Oh, yes, Father certainly would.
answer: Wait a minute . . .

question: Huh?
answer: That's your father's diary, Ann.

question: Father's . . . I never knew he had a diary.
answer: There's enough in it for a hundred speeches, things people ought to hear nowadays. You be careful of it, won't you dear? It's always helped keep your father alive for me.

question: You've got swell form. Must have been a pretty good pitcher.
answer: Pretty good? Say, I was just about ready for the major leagues when I chipped a bone in my elbow. I got it pitchin' a nineteen-inning game!

question: Nineteen!
answer: Yep. There was a major league scout there watching me, too. And he came down after the game with a contract. Do you know what? I couldn't life my arm to sign it. But I'll be okay again as soon as I get it fixed up. What do you mean, too bad? Well, what are you talking about? I just told you I was gonna get a

question: Well, I was just thinking about this John Doe business. Why, as soon as it comes out it's all a fake, you'll be washed up in baseball, won't you?
answer: Y-yeah. Gee, doggone it, I never thought about that. Gosh!

question: Hello, John. All set for the big night? Swell! Okay, Beany, take them outside. Now, look, John. Here's the speech. It's in caps and double-spaced. You won't have any trouble reading it. Not nervous, are you?
answer: No.

question: Of course not. He wouldn't be.
answer: Who?

question: Come on, out. Out!
answer: Who?

question: John Doe, the one in the speech.
answer: Oh. Yeah.

question: You know something? I've actually fallen in love with him.
answer: All right, there he is, sister. Now, come onplenty of oomph!

question: What's the idea?
answer: No, no, no. Now that's too much!

question: This is no time for cheap publicity, Mr. Connell!
answer: Listen. If that guy lays an egg. I want to get something out of it. I'm getting a Jane Doe ready!

question: We've existed since time began. We built the pyramids, we saw Christ crucified, pulled the oars for Roman emperors, sailed the boats for Columbus, retreated from Moscow with Napoleon and froze with Washington at Valley Forge!
answer: Because we're the people and we're tough!

question: They've started a lot of talk about free people going softthat we can't take it. That's a lot of hooey! . . . A free people can beat the world at anything, from war to tiddle-de-winks, if we all pull in the same direction! I know a lot of you are saying "What can I do? I'm just a little punk. I don't count." Well, you're dead wrong! The little punks have always counted because in the long run the character of a country is the sum total of the character of its little punks.
answer: But we've all got to get in there and pitch! We can't win the old ball game unless we have team work. And that's where every John Doe comes in! It's up to him to get together with his teammate!

question: And your teammates, my friends, is the guy next door to you. Your neighbor! He's a terribly important guy, that guy next door! You're gonna need him and he's gonna need you . . . so look him up! If he's sick, call on him! If he's hungry, feed him! If he's out of a job, find him one! To most of you, your neighbor is a stranger, a guy with a barking dog, and a high fence around him.
answer: Now, you can't be a stranger to any guy that's on your own team. So tear down the fence that separates you, tear down the fence and you'll tear down a lot of hates and prejudices! Tear down all the fences in the country and you'll really have teamwork! I know a lot of you are saying to yourselves

question: Now you're talking! Gangway, you heelots! I knew you'd wake up sooner or later! Boy, am I glad we got out of that mess.
answer: I had that five thousand bucks sewed up! Could have been on my way to old Doc Brown!

question: Yeah, she's a heelot just like the rest of them. It's lucky you got away from her.
answer: What was I doin' up there makin' a speech, anyway? Me? Huh? Gee, the more I think about it the more I could . . .

question: Tear down all the fences. Why, if you tore one picket off of your neighbor's fence he'd sue you!
answer: Five thousand bucks! I had it right in my hand!

question: Jitterbugs.
answer: Yeh. Say, how much money we got left?

question: Four bits.
answer: Better make it doughnuts, huh?

question: Look, Mr. Norton, I think you've got a lot of nerve having those people hold us here. Well, if there's nobody holding us here, let's get going. Incidentally, my name isn't Doe. It's Willoughby.
answer: Uh-huh. To carry out the principles you talked about in your radio speech. Oh, but you don't know how big this thing is. You should see the thousands of telegrams we've received and what they're saying about you.

question: Look, it started as a circulation stunt, didn't it?
answer: Uh-huh . . .

question: Well, you got your circulation. Now, why don't you let me alone?
answer: Oh, it started as a circulation stunt, but it isn't any more. Mr. Norton wants to get back of it and sponsor John Doe Clubs all over the country. He wants to send you on a lecture tour.

question: Me?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Say, let's get something straight here. I don't want any part of this thing. If you've got an idea I'm going around lecturing to people, why you're crazy! Baseball's my racket, and I'm sticking to it. Come on, Colonel, let's get out of here.
answer: John!

question: This is Sourpuss. Er, excuse me. Er, Mr. Smithers, Mr. Doe.
answer: Ththat's all right. If you didn't call me Sourpuss, it wouldn't feel natural.

question: Well, anyway, II guess nearly everybody in the neighborhood came, except the DeLaneys. The Delaneys live in a big house with an iron fence around it and they always keep their blinds drawn, and we always figured that he was just an old miser that sat back counting his money, so why bother about inviting him? Until Grimes, the milkman spoke up and he said, "Say, you've got the Delaneys all wrong." And then he tells
answer: Old man Delaney has been bringing his furniture over to my place at night, one piece at a time, and selling it.

question: Yeah. And, well, sir, a half a dozen of us ran over there to fetch them and we got them to the meeting. What a reception they got. Why, everybody shook hands with them and made a fuss over them, and, well, finally, Mr. and Mrs. Delaney just sat right down and cried.
answer: And then we started to find out about a lot of other people.

question: Well, we leave for the airport in half an hour. Is that Johnny-boy's room? I'd better hustle him up!
answer: He'll be ready on time. He's packing now.

question: Ah, good!
answer: Yeah.

question: I gotta give you credit, Annie-girl. I've handled a good many big promotions in my time . . . everything from the world's fair to a channel swimmer, but this one has certainly got me spinning. And now a John Doe Convention! Wow! Say! If you could only get him to jump off the City Hall roof on Christmas Eve, I'd guarantee you half a million people there.
answer: Charlie!

question: Who, Johnny-boy? Well, I don't know what angle you want, but I'll give it to you quick. Number one, he's got great yokel appeal; but he's a nice guy. Number two, he's beginning to believe he really wrote that original suicide letter that you made up. Number three, he thinks that you're Joan of Arc or something! Number four, well, you know what number four is. He's nuts about you. Yeah, it's running out of his ears.
answer: You left out number five. We're all heels, me especially.

question: No, thank you.
answer: Do you care if I sit down out here?

question: No. About me?
answer: There was, there was something I was trying to stop you from doing. So, er, so I got up out of bed and I walked right through the wall here, right straight into your room. And there you were in bed. And very pretty, too. So, I shook you, and the moment you opened your eyes, you hopped out of bed and started running like the devil, in your nightgown. Dreams are sure crazy, aren't they? Well, would you like to know who it was you were marrying? No, not that bad. It was a fella that sends you flowers every day. Er, what's his name? Mr. Norton's nephew. Yeah, that's the one. But here's the funniest part of it all. I was the fella up there doing the marrying. You know, the Justice of the Peace or something . . .

question: You were? I thought you were chasing me?
answer: Well, yes, I was. But I was your father then, see? But the real me, John Doe, er, that is, Long John Willoughby, I was the fellow up there with the book. You know what I mean? Well, I took you across my knee and I started spanking you. And all the time, er, the guy up there, you know, with the book, me, just stood there nodding his head and he said, "Go to it, Pop, whack her one for me, because that's just the way I feel about it, too."

question: Oh, somebody else sitting there?
answer: And this is your coat.

question: Mine? Oh! Oh! Oh, it's lovely!
answer: And a new contract goes with it.

question: Oh, John. Come in.
answer: Say, I'm kindait's raining out a little

question: That's all right.
answer: Flowers.

question: I'm terribly sorry she isn't here.
answer: She isn't?

question: No, she just left. I'm surprised you didn't run into her. She went over to Mr. Norton's house.
answer: Oh!

question: Did you want to see her about something important?
answer: Yeah. I, uh, well . . . No. It'll wait. Say, my coat's pretty wet. I'm afraid I might have wet the couch a little. Well, I guess I'll see her at the convention later.

question: Yes, of course. I'll see that she gets the flowers.
answer: Thanks. Good night, Mrs. Mitchell.

question: I married him. Uh-huh.
answer: Yeah, yeah, but look, Mrs. Mitchell, you know I love Ann and it's gonna be awfully hard for me to say it because, well, you know, she's so wonderful, and, well, the best I ever was was a bush-league pitcher. And you know, I think she's in love with another man, the one she made up. You know, the real John Doe. Well, that's pretty tough competition. I bet you he'd know how to say it all right. And me, I get up to it and around it and in back of it, but, but I never get right to it. Do you know what I mean? So the only chance I've got is, well, if somebody could kinda give her a warning sort of, sorta prepare her for the shock!

question: You mean you'd like me to do it, huh?
answer: Well, I was thinking thatYeah, you know, sort of break the ice.

question: Hello, bodyguards! Hey, had your dinner yet? Well, look. No. Go ahead and have your dinner. I'll Hello, Mr. Connell.
answer: Hiyah, John. Oh, quiet, quiet, quiet.

question: No, I never read the speeches before I make them. I get more of a kick out of it that way.
answer: Yep, I'm hard. But you want to know something? I've got a weakness. You'd never guess that, would you? Well, I have. Want to know what it is? The Star Spangled Banner.

question: Yeah.
answer: Oh, back there, huh? You weren't old enough for the first world war, were you? Course not. Must have been a kid. I was. I was just ripe. And rarin' to go. I saw him get it. I was right there and saw it with my own eyes. Now, that's all right, isn't it?

question: You betcha.
answer: All right. And we don't want anybody coming around changing it, do we?

question: No, sir.
answer: No, sir. And when they do I get mad! I get b-boiling mad. And right now, John, I'm sizzling! I get mad for a lot of other guys besides myselfI get mad for a guy named Washington! And a guy named Jeffersonand Lincoln. Lighthouses, John! Lighthouses in a foggy world! You know what I mean?

question: Yeah. It certainly is.
answer: And you'd feel like an awful sucker if you found yourself marching right in the middle of it, wouldn't you? And you, of course you wouldn't know it because you're gentle. But that's what you're doing. You're mixed up with a skunk, my boy, a no-good, dangerous skunk!

question: Say, you're not talking about Mr. Norton, are you? You must be wrong, Mr. Connell, 'cause he's been marvelous about the John Doe Clubs. Sure.
answer: Sure. I don't blame you. So am I. All right! Now, supposing a certain unmentionable worm, whose initials are D. B., was trying to use that to shove his way into the White House. So he could put the screws on, so he could turn out the lights in those lighthouses. What would you say about that? Huh?

question: Nobody's gonna do that, Mr. Connell. They can't use the John Doe Clubs for politics. That's the main idea.
answer: Is that so? Then what's a big political boss like Hammett doing in town? And a labor leader like Bennett? And a lot of other big shots who are up at D. B.'s house right now? Wolves, John, wolves waiting to cut up the John Does!

question: You're all wet. Miss Mitchell writes those speeches and nobody can make her write that kind of stuff.
answer: Don't write 'em? Why, that gold-grabbin' dame would double-cross her own mother for a handful of Chinese yen!

question: Don't write 'em? Why, that gold-grabbin' dame would double-cross her own mother for a handful of Chinese yen!
answer: Hey!

question: Go on and read it, John, and then start socking!
answer: Hey, wait a minute, Mr. Doe!

question: Elevators ain't running.
answer: Colonel!

question: You shouldn't have gotten out of bed, Miss.
answer: Has he been here?

question: No.
answer: Have you seen him? Where's Connell?

question: He's watching the other door.
answer: Oh. Gee, you're swell! Oh.
